column1: 1999nvm..conf...36K|1999|Lunar Meteorites and Implications for Compositional Remote Sensing of the Lunar Surface|Korotev
column2: R. L.|New Views of the Moon 2: Understanding the Moon Through the Integration of Diverse Datasets|||36|Lunar meteorites (LMs) are rocks found on Earth that were ejected from the Moon by impact of an asteroidal meteoroid. Three factors make the LMs important to remote-sensing studies: (1) Most are breccias composed of regolith or fragmental material; (2) all are rocks that resided (or breccias composed of material that resided) in the upper few meters of the Moon prior to launch and (3) most apparently come from areas distant from the Apollo sites. How Many Lunar Locations? At this writing (June 1999)
column3: there are 18 known lunar meteorite specimens. When unambiguous cases of terrestrial pairing are considered
column4: the number of actual LMs reduces to 13. (Terrestrial pairing is when a single piece of lunar rock entered Earth's atmosphere
column5: but multiple fragments were produced because the meteoroid broke apart on entry
column6: upon hitting the ground or ice
column7: or while being transported through the ice.) We have no reason to believe that LMs preferentially derive from any specific region(s) of the Moon; i.e.
column8: we believe that they are samples from random locations. However
column9: we do not know how many different locations are represented by the LMs; mathematically
column10: it could be as few as 1 or as many as 13. The actual maximum is < 13 because in some cases a single impact appears to have yielded more than one LM. Yamato 793169 and Asuka 881757 are considered "source-crater paired" or "launch paired" because they are compositionally and petrographically similar to each other and distinct from the others
column11: and both have similar cosmic-ray exposure (CRE) histories. The same can be said of QUE 94281 and Y 793274. Thus the 13 meteorites probably represent a maximum of 11 locations on the Moon. The minimum number of likely source craters is debated and in flux as new data for different isotopic systems are obtained. Conservatively
column13: a minimum of about 5 impacts is required. Compositional and petrographic data offer only probabilistic constraints. An extreme
column15: is that such data offer no constraint. For example
column16: if one were to cut up the Apollo 17 landing site (which was selected for its diversity) into softball-sized pieces
column18: sample 70135) would be crystalline mare basalts like Y 793169 whereas others (e.g.
column19: sample 73131 would be feldspathic regolith breccias like MAC 88104/ 88105. However
column20: nature is not so devious. Warren argues that LMs come from craters of only a few kilometers in diameter. If so
column23: that ALHA 81005 and Y 791197) were launched simultaneously from the same crater
column24: the probability is nevertheless low because the two meteorites are compositionally and mineralogically distinct. Thus
column25: within the allowed range (5-11) for the number of locations represented by the LMs
column26: values at the high end of the range are probably more likely. Mare Meteorites: Three LMs consist almost entirely of mare basalt. Two
column30: crystalline rocks that are compositionally and mineralogically similar (but not identical) to each other; they probably derive from a single lunar-mare location. The third
column32: is a fragmental breccia consisting predominantly of VLT mare basalt. Thus
column33: these LMs probably represent only two lunar mare locations. The basaltic LMs have mineral and bulk compositions distinct from Apollo mare basalts. The petrography of Calcalong Creek has not been described in detail
column34: but compositionally it is unique in that it corresponds to a mixture (breccia) of about one-half feldspathic material (i.e.
column35: the mean composition of the feldspathic lunar meteorites
column39: and 1% CI chondrite. With 4 micro g/g Th and correspondingly high concentrations of other incompatible elements
column40: it is the only lunar meteorite that is likely to have come from within the Procellarum KREEP Terrane (PKT). Yamato 793274 and QUE 94281 are together distinct in being fragmental breccias containing subequal parts of feldspathic highland material and VLT mare basalt. Jolliff et al. estimate a mare to highland ratio of 54:46 for QUE 94281 and 62:38 for Y 793274; this difference is well within the range observed for soils collected only centimeters apart (in cores) at interface site like Apollo 15 and 17 [11]. Although the two meteorites were found on opposite sides of Antarctica
column41: they are probably launch-paired. The strongest evidence is that the pyroclastic glass spherules that occur in both are of two compositional groups and the two groups are essentially the same in both meteorites. Yamato 791197 is nominally a feldspathic lunar meteorite (below)
column43: it probably contains the highest abundance of clasts and glasses of mare derivation. As a consequence
column44: its composition is at the high-Fe
column45: low-Mg end of the range for FLMs and is not included in the FLM average of Table 1. Its composition is consistent with about 10% mare-derived material. Similarly
column46: the two small (Y 82) pieces of Y 82192/82193186032 are more mafic than the large (Y 86) piece
column47: probably as a result of about 7% mare-derived material. All Apollo missions went to areas in or near the PKT
column50: all Apollo regolith samples are contaminated with Th-rich material from the PKT. At the nominally "typical" highland site
column52: about 30% of the regolith (<1-mm fines) is Th-rich ejecta from the Imbrium impact and about 6% is mare material probably derived from mare basins. Thus Apollo 16 regolith is not typical of the highlands. Among Apollo rocks
column53: the compositions of the FLMs correspond most closely to the feldspathic granulitic breccias of Apollo 16 and 17. (Additional information is contained in original)|
